reference_summary: Hareton takes Cathy's side in an argument, when Heathcliff is about to strike her. Heathcliff admits to Nelly that he is being tormented by the thoughts and reminders of Catherine.

generated_summary:
1. The speaker, Peterboel, is a peasant who owns a prosperous farm in Denmark with his wife.
    2. They have no children, and often lament their lack of an heir.
    3. One year, they adopt a bull calf named Peter, who they call their son and heir.
    4. They hire a clerk to teach Peter to talk, but the clerk warns them that it is forbidden and will cost them a lot of money.
    5. The peasant and his wife spend a lot of money on Peter's education, but he runs away just as they are about to see him graduate.
    6. The clerk finds out that Peter has become a merchant in a town at a distance and reads about it in a newspaper.
    7. The peasant sets out to find Peter and brings a large sum of money with him.
    8. When he arrives at the town, he recognizes Peter and takes him back to their farm.
    9. Peter becomes the heir of the peasant's wealth, and they live with him till their dying day.
reference_summary: An older couple wishes that they had an heir. They have a bull calf that they adore, named Peter. They devise a plan to teach Peter to talk so that he may become their heir. They ask the clerk to help them in their endeavours. After a large investment, they are disappointed that they still have not seen Peter or evidence of his improvement. The clerk arrives to explain what has happened, and the man sets off in search of his “son.” All ends happily for everyone involved.

reference_summary: A king is determined to have a child, so his queen sees an old woman who helps her to bear a child through enchantment. There are limitations—the king and queen cannot see their child until she is fourteen. The king decides to break this rule of the contract, and the princess dies. He is then forced to put her body in the church with a sentinel standing guard. However, finding a sentinel starts to become a challenge when those who volunteer disappear. A young smith who wishes to show his bravery is the first to last the night, and his drunken bravery earns him rewards.

generated_summary:
1) A woodcutter's wife and three daughters are traveling through the forest when they get separated.
    2) The youngest daughter finds her way to an old man's house, but is let fall into a cellar.
    3) The old man asks his beasts what they say, and they reply, "ducks," and the girl is let fall into the cellar again.
    4) The youngest daughter goes to the old man's house for the third time and is let in by the old man, who asks his beasts what they say, and they reply, "ducks."
    5) The old man offers the girl food and a night's lodging, but she refuses to eat with the beasts and instead tends to them, feeding them barley and straw.
    6) The old man's servants arrive, and the king's son, who was transformed into an old man, reveals that he is now free from the spell and that the maiden is the one who broke it.
    7) The king's son tells his servants to fetch the maiden's parents to be present at the wedding feast.
    8) The summary ends with the old man's servants leading the two sisters away to serve a charcoal burner until they improve and never again suffer poor animals to go hungry.
reference_summary: A father asks for his daughters to bring him lunch in the woods, but the birds eat up the trails he has left. The daughters each in turn find a small house with a little old man and three beasts. There they are tested.

generated_summary:
1. Catherine, a poor girl, was persecuted by her destiny for seven years.
    2. Her mistress's destiny tore everything in pieces and flung them on the floor when Catherine fled through the open door.
    3. Catherine served a noble lady for seven years and hoped she might now be left in peace.
    4. Destiny came forth and forced her to leave each house.
    5. Catherine's mistress's destiny brought her a ball of silk, which Catherine used to get married to the king.
    6. The wise woman at the court predicted that Catherine would die a queen.
    7. The king married Catherine instead of the bride he had promised to wed.
reference_summary: Catherine is living a happy life, until one day her Destiny steps in and asks a fateful question. Things change for Catherine, and she finds herself wandering the world, always looking for a new place to work. After some time has passed, her life is not so bad, but not so good either. She and her lady come up with a plan to try to appease her Destiny. A ball of silk is the offer made, and Catherine finds just how important a ball of silk can be.

generated_summary:
1. Three brothers and a sister lived together in a small cottage, loved one another, and worked hard to build a palace.
    2. An old woman told them that their palace was perfect but needed a church, and they built one.
    3. The oldest brother wanted to seek the water of life, a talking bird, and a branch of the tree of beauty, and the old man gave him a knife to mark the path.
    4. The young man walked to the mountain, met a giant, and asked if he had seen two young men pass. The giant said they never came back.
    5. The sister took out the knife and found the blade was red as blood, indicating that something terrible had happened to her brother.
    6. The young man asked the giant for advice on how to free his brothers and find the treasures.
    7. The girl set out for the mountain and climbed, despite the scoffs and jeers from the stones.
    8. She reached the top and found the pool of the water of life, the tree of beauty, and a talking bird.
    9. She filled a brazen pitcher with water and took the bird, branch, and stone.
    10. She went down the mountain and sprinkled the water on the stones, turning them into young men and girls.
    11. The fame of the wonders spread, and the king's son came to see them, admiring the maiden's courage and beauty.
    12. The prince asked her hand in marriage, and they lived happily ever after.
reference_summary: Three brothers and one sister work hard to build a palace. They are happy until a visitor tells them what their palace is missing. Each sets out in turn to bring back the water of life, the tree of beauty, and the talking bird. Unfortunately each of the brothers is unsuccessful, and all seems lost until the sister manages to make her way to the mountaintop.

generated_summary:
1. The young man, who wanted to marry the king's daughter, built a ship that could float on both land and sea and went to the king with the ship.
    2. The king set a task for the young man, which he accomplished with the help of a holy hermit.
    3. The young man married the king's daughter with the help of the holy hermit.
reference_summary: A king advertises that he will wed his daughter to one who can make a ship that will float on both land and sea. Three brothers each have their hand at building such a ship, but the kindness of the youngest allows him success, as he befriends a holy hermit. The group journeys to the kingdom, picking up friends along the way. Unfortunately, the king changes the rules when they arrive, but the man's new friends help him to meet the king’s demands.

reference_summary: A king and his wife make a bet, but the result is unfair to the queen, who is banished to the forest. There a farmer takes her in and she raises her son until he is eighteen. He leaves in search of adventure, only to find himself at his father’s castle. He is given seemingly impossible tasks, which he completes with the help of a fairy. Finally, the king is taught the error of his ways.

reference_summary: A king has two daughters, though one is ugly and cruel and the other beautiful and kind. A prince is supposed to be promised to the former, but falls in love with the latter. The bitter sister and the king send away the younger princess to a tower where she is trapped. The prince tries to see his princess, but is harmed by the plans of the elder sister.The princess escapes her tower and sets off to save the prince she loves.

generated_summary:
1. The old woman found a snake in her brass pot while bathing in the river.
    2. She took the snake home and kept it as a pet, not knowing it was deadly.
    3. The snake turned into a prince and demanded that the princess tell him his birth secret.
    4. The princess kept silent and refused to tell the prince his birth secret.
    5. The prince disappeared and the princess lived in mourning for him for five years.
    6. One night, the princess found mud stains in her room, indicating the prince had visited her.
    7. The prince revealed himself to the princess and told her he had been turned into a snake by an enchantment.
    8. The princess promised to tell the prince his birth secret if he returned to her.
    9. The prince disappeared again and the princess lived in mourning for him.
    10. The princess discovered that the snake that visited her was the prince in disguise.
    11. The princess conquered her fear and stood up to the Queen of Snakes, demanding the prince's return.
    12. The Queen of Snakes promised to return the prince the next day.
    13. The princess prepared for the prince's return, adorning her home and preparing a feast.
    14. At midnight, the prince returned in his original form, and the princess ran to embrace him.
    15. The prince and princess returned to the palace and lived happily ever after.
reference_summary: An old woman who has nothing finds a snake in her water jar, and wishes for death. Instead, she discovers a necklace, which earns her wealth. The king buys the necklace, but finds it replaced with the son he so desires.The prince and princess are wed, but she wishes to know the secret of the prince. He warns her of the consequences, which come to pass when he reveals the secret. The princess must work to break the enchantment to get back her prince.

reference_summary: Many are enchanted by the mountains but none leave alive. A family loses their seven sons to the mountain until the youngest sets out to try to do what his brothers could not. He manages to break the enchantment, and meets Zoulvisia. Out of kindness, he brings an old woman back to the palace, despite the misgivings of others. The woman is a witch, and Zoulvisia reveals secrets to her that put their lives in danger. The prince and Zoulvisia plan her escape.

reference_summary: A spoiled young boy torments an old woman, who curses him to fall in love with the silent princess. He decides he must go into the world and seek this princess, or die. He comes to learn that many others have lost their lives trying to get the silent princess to speak. Luckily, he befriends a nightingale who helps him in his challenges.

generated_summary:
1. A shepherd refuses to say "To your good health" to a king, despite being threatened with various punishments.
    2. The king becomes increasingly angry and offers the shepherd various rewards, including a princess, if he will only say the phrase.
    3. The shepherd continues to refuse, even when the king offers him the entire kingdom.
    4. Eventually, the king becomes so pleased with the shepherd's refusal that he offers him his own daughter in marriage.
    5. The shepherd agrees to marry the princess, but only on the condition that he does not have to say "To your good health."
    6. The king is delighted and the two are married.
    7. The shepherd becomes a successful king and is loved by his people for not forcing them to wish him well against their wills.
reference_summary: A young shepherd refuses to abide by the laws of the kingdom when the king sneezes. The shepherd survives three perilous trials and refused three magnificent gifts for the hand of the princess in marriage, which he eventually gets out of the king’s frustration.

generated_summary:
1. Abu Nawas's wife dies and he comes to the Sultan for help.
    2. The Sultan gives Abu Nawas a wedding suit, a thousand gold pieces, and soft carpets for his house.
    3. Abu Nawas and his wife spend their money and sell their fine things, until they have nothing left.
    4. Abu Nawas goes to the Sultan and pretends that he is dead, to get money for his wife's burial.
    5. The Sultan sends his doorkeeper to find out which of them is dead, and it is revealed that Abu Nawas's wife is dead.
    6. Abu Nawas pretends to be dead again to fool the Sultan, and the Sultan is tricked again.
    7. The Sultan gives Abu Nawas the money he promised, and Abu Nawas and his wife continue to live off of the Sultan's generosity.
reference_summary: Abu Nowas went to the Sultan telling of his dead wife. The Sultan got him a new wife and a decent dowry, which was spent almost immediately. Abu Nowas is able to trick both the Sultan and the Sultana and gets more money for his cunning.

reference_summary: An old couple was never able to have children and the old man sets out to find one. Through magic he acquires a daughter, but she is stolen by an eagle. The eagle takes care of her because he sees her as a good omen and she grows up in his nest. Later in her life, she is discovered by a prince. The girl is tricked by an old woman and brought down from the trees in order to marry the prince and lives happily ever after.

generated_summary:
1. A poor youth lived in a small cottage with his lazy, stupid son.
    2. The old man died, leaving his son with nothing to eat but pears from his tree.
    3. A fox appeared and offered to take the youth to the king in exchange for some pears.
    4. The youth agreed and the fox took him to the king, who asked for the youth's hand in marriage to his daughter.
    5. The youth was afraid and the fox told him not to worry, he would take care of everything.
    6. The youth put on a fine coat and horse and rode to the palace, where he married the princess.
    7. After a week of feasting, the fox told the king that Count Pirro wished to take his young bride home to his own castle.
    8. The king agreed and the wedding party set out, with the fox running ahead.
    9. Along the way, the fox met a flock of sheep belonging to an ogre and a herd of pigs belonging to the same ogre.
    10. The fox told the king that the animals belonged to Count Pirro, saving them from the king's soldiers.
    11. The king was pleased and the fox continued to guide them to the castle.
    12. When they arrived, the fox crept downstairs and burned the ogre and his wife in the oven.
    13. The king left the bridal pair in the castle and the fox returned to the cottage, where he pretended to be dead.
    14. The princess was devastated and promised to give the fox a magnificent coffin and bury him with honors.
    15. The fox allowed himself to be softened and lived in the castle for many years, playing with Count Pirro's children.
    16. When he died, the princess had him buried in a silver coffin and followed him to the grave.
reference_summary: A poor beggar boy is left with nothing but a beautiful pear tree when his father dies. A fox sees the pear tree and promises to bring him good luck if he does what he is told. His life is transformed and the fox asks only for a coffin when he dies because he is the one responsible for the former beggar’s good fortune.
